inputs:
In what follows, we provide short narratives, each of which illustrates a common proverb. 
Narrative: John was always boasting about his wealth and success to his friends. One day, he lost all his money in a bad investment and had to sell his house and car. His friends were surprised and didn't know how to react. They realized that John had been living beyond his means and that his boasting had been empty.
This narrative is a good illustration of the following proverb:
targets: Pride goes before a fall
multiple_choice_targets: People who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones
Good things come in small packages
Don't put new wine into old bottles
Beat swords into ploughshares
Practice what you preach
A man who is his own lawyer has a fool for his client
A barking dog never bites
He who pays the piper calls the tune
April showers bring forth May flowers
Fish always stink from the head down
Absolute power corrupts absolutely
Jack of all trades, master of none
The wages of sin is death
Love of money is the root of all evil
Christmas comes but once a year
What's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander
It's the squeaky wheel that gets the grease
Practice makes perfect
The age of miracles is past
An army marches on its stomach
If the mountain won't come to Mohammed, then Mohammed must go to the mountain
A soft answer turneth away wrath
Honey catches more flies than vinegar
Dead men tell no tales
Build a better mousetrap and the world will beat a path to your doorLink to proverb
Revenge is a dish best served cold
All publicity is good publicity
Don't meet troubles half-way
First impressions are the most lasting
It takes two to tango
An Englishman's home is his castle
Little things please little minds
Cut your coat to suit your cloth
Look before you leap
Cheaters never win and winners never cheat
A golden key can open any door
A prophet is not recognized in his own land
Silence is golden
Success has many fathers, while failure is an orphan
God helps those who help themselves
Laughter is the best medicine
There's no accounting for tastes
Do unto others as you would have them do to you
A stitch in time saves nine
Never judge a book by its cover
Hard cases make bad law
A house divided against itself cannot stand
Time is money
That which does not kill us makes us stronger
Seek and you shall find
Failing to plan is planning to fail
The cobbler always wears the worst shoes
You are never too old to learn
He who laughs last laughs longest
Don't shoot the messenger
Good things come to those that wait
Seeing is believing
Hindsight is always twenty-twenty
Only fools and horses work
Flattery will get you nowhere
Nothing new under the sun
What can't be cured must be endured
A cat may look at a king
No rest for the wicked
Virtue is its own reward
Once bitten, twice shy
Haste makes waste
A nod's as good as a wink to a blind horse
The best things in life are free
Strike while the iron is hot
From the sublime to the ridiculous is only one step
Distance lends enchantment to the view
To err is human; to forgive divine
He who hesitates is lost
You can't hold with the hare and run with the hounds
A poor workman always blames his tools
Feed a cold and starve a fever
Finders keepers, losers weepers
Make haste slowly
Great oaks from little acorns grow
Live for today for tomorrow never comes
It takes a thief to catch a thief
It's better to light a candle than to curse the darkness
There's honour among thieves
Money doesn't grow on trees
Between two stools one falls to the ground
Give credit where credit is due
The apple never falls far from the tree
Nothing is certain but death and taxes
Cleanliness is next to godliness
Bad news travels fast
Life is what you make it
The customer is always right
One hand washes the other
Don't let the grass grow under your feet
The end justifies the means
For want of a nail the shoe was lost; for want of a shoe the horse was lost; and for want of a horse the man was lost
Possession is nine points of the law
An apple a day keeps the doctor away
Marriages are made in heaven

inputs:
In what follows, we provide short narratives, each of which illustrates a common proverb. 
Narrative: Sarah was always very careful with her money. She saved every penny she could and never spent more than she needed to. Her friends would often tease her for being so frugal. One day, Sarah’s car broke down and she needed to pay for an expensive repair. She was able to pay for it without any trouble because of all the money she had saved.
This narrative is a good illustration of the following proverb:
targets: A penny saved is a penny earned
multiple_choice_targets: A penny saved is a penny earned
All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy
The squeaky wheel gets the grease
When in Rome, do as the Romans do
The early bird catches the worm
You can’t make an omelette without breaking eggs
A stitch in time saves nine
All that glitters is not gold
Where there’s smoke there’s fire
The proof of the pudding is in the eating
